In the simulation, the devices are uniformly randomly distributed in a square area of 100Ã—100100100100\times 100 m2 on the ground.
The three-dimensional coordinates of the BS and RIS are (0,0,25)0025(0,0,25) m and (20,20,20)202020(20,20,20) m, respectively.
The path loss is L=C0â€‹(d/D0)âˆ’Î½ğ¿subscriptğ¶0superscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ·0ğœˆL={C_{0}}({d}/{D_{0}})^{-\nu}, where C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0} denotes the path loss at the reference distance D0=1subscriptğ·01D_{0}=1 m and C0=0â€‹dBmsubscriptğ¶00dBmC_{0}=0~{}\text{dBm} by default, dğ‘‘d is the distance between the transmitter and receiver, and Î½ğœˆ\nu is the path loss exponent.
The path loss exponents from the devices to the BS, from the devices to the RIS, and from the RIS to the BS are set to Î½dâ€‹b=3.2subscriptğœˆğ‘‘ğ‘3.2\nu_{db}=3.2, Î½dâ€‹r=2.6subscriptğœˆğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ2.6\nu_{dr}=2.6, and Î½râ€‹b=2.2subscriptğœˆğ‘Ÿğ‘2.2\nu_{rb}=2.2, respectively.
We consider Rician fading between the devices and RIS, and between the RIS and BS with the Rician factors of Îºdâ€‹r=10subscriptğœ…ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ10\kappa_{dr}=10 and Îºrâ€‹b=10subscriptğœ…ğ‘Ÿğ‘10\kappa_{rb}=10, respectively.
Two scenarios are considered between the devices and BS.
In the first scenario, we consider the Rician fading with Rician factor Îºdâ€‹b=2subscriptğœ…ğ‘‘ğ‘2\kappa_{db}=2.
In the second scenario, we consider the Rayleigh fading to emulate the situation where the devices are located in blind spots, i.e., the LoS paths from the devices to the BS are blocked.
The channel estimation errors are measured by the NMSE Î¹=ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ‡âˆ’ğ‡^â€–F2]/ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ‡^â€–F2]ğœ„ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormğ‡^ğ‡ğ¹2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm^ğ‡ğ¹2\iota=\mathbb{E}[\|{\bf{H}}-{\widehat{\bf{H}}}\|_{F}^{2}]/\mathbb{E}[\|{\widehat{\bf{H}}}\|_{F}^{2}], over all linksÂ [18].
Î¹=0ğœ„0\iota=0 indicates perfect CSI.
Unless otherwise specified, other parameters are listed in TableÂ II.
